A footnote must be that stations and networks recently found it tragically
necessary to program in response to the assassination of Senator Robert F.
Kennedy. NET scheduled a 2 1/2 hour memorial program for the Senator
June 7, including musical segments from New York's Lincoln Center t Cleveland's
Shiloh Baptist Church, and the Los Angeles Philharmonic. A eulogy was read
by Theodore Sorensen, and a film shown of an interview with Senator Kennedy
by James Day, manager, KQED, San Francisco. A NET Journal on "This
Question of Violence" was rushed to completion for showing, June 10. Over
the weekend, the EEN and individual stations departed from their regular schedule
to rebroadcast past programs which were appropriate in paying tribute to the
Senator's memory.
As this report was prepared, the Ford Foundation announced major grants
to educational stations and regional networks under the Foundation's Project for
New Television Programming.
With this financial aid, WGBHr Boston will produce 20 one-hour dramas on
contemporary Negro life. WI DT, New Yo.k will produce 39 one-hour program's,
"Where It's At," a series exploring the social, cultural and artistic life of Negroes
in Harlem, the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn and Newark KLRN,
Austin, Texas will broadcast 39 one-hour programs on Mexican-American comÂ¬
munity affairs. "Cleveland Now" will be an hour-weekly series on plans to
revitalize the city, on WVIZ, Cleveland. WOLN, Erie, Pennsylvania will carry
10 one-hour reports and discussion on local housing needs. KUHT, Houston,
Texas will produce a consumer education series for low-income residents. KCET,
Los.Angeles, will produce 70 half-hour programs on the daily drama of life in
Spanish-speaking sections of the city. WYES, New Orleans, will broadcast 156
one-hour programs on issues related to the Negro community. In South Carolina,
the ETV network will provide 18 half-hour programs of information and education
on job opportunities for the unemployed. Several other stations and networks
will produce general public affairs series which, while not directed exclusively
to "ghetto" problems or populations,may be expected to treat such issues directly
from time to time. San Francisco's KQED will revive its 45-minute "Newspaper
of the Air." WITF, Hershey, Pennsylvania will produce a series of broadcasts
on significant community activites. WJCT, Jacksonville, will air 150 one-hour
programs on a news magazine format, treating local and state affairs. The New
Hampshire network will produce 34 one-hour news magazine programs for coverage
of state and regional issues. The Eastern Educational Network will continue its
series of cooperative productions on public affairs and special events coverage
(such as those described here. )
Besides cooperative production with regional and national networks,
many ETV stations continue to produce and plan for special programming dealing
with local community problems, or put local perspective on the national issues
involved.
